ej wrote:

>Colin Green wrote:
>  
>
>>{Idea] Many stock price movements are unpredictable, but some of the
>>movements may be predictable after effects of the unpredictable moves.
>>Therefore the key in making money would be to be ability to determine
>>when the predictable movements are occuring (or are about to occur) and
>>to trade based on the prediction, and to ignore all other
>>non-predictable movements. Therefore something akin to a confidence
>>output would probably be a good thing, so instead of always trying to
>>predict tomorrows price the network has the ability to admit that it
>>doesn't 'understand' the current conditions and therefore won't be
>>making a prediction today.
>>
>>Colin.
>>    
>>
>
>
>This is EXACTLY what I'm trying to do. Events which happen out of the 
>blue like Septembet the 11th happen very infrequently.
>What's more likely to happen is an event will develop over a period of 
>weeks, and the thing driving the price will be the sum total
>psychology of all the traders.
>  
>
Yeh, en masse group dynamics take over and the stock movements 
[theoretically] take over. Emyr, I understand you're in the UK - I think 
there is a going to be an episode of Horizon about stock market 
prediction sometime this season, dunno when though, I spotted it in the 
BBC's current advert for the new season. New Scientist did an article a 
few months back also, along the lines of  - the world economies could be 
stabilised if accurate prediction models could be built.

>I plan to 'show' the last N days worth of stock data to the network and 
>get it to return a number from
> -1 to +1 based on sell through to buy.
>
I would say you need some leeway either way of the historical min/max to 
allow for new highs and lows. I also am a great believer in doing as 
much work with traditional techniques as possible, don't try to evolve 
behaviour to do things you can do in other ways. e.g. I wouldn't try and 
obtaining a buy/sell signal, instead I might ask it to predict a price 
and a confidence value, I can then run this data through a simple bit of 
logic to determine if I should buy or sell. I have therefore removed the 
necessity to for the network to perform that last bit of functionality. 
The less a network has to do, the more chance there is of finding a 
network that actually works.

Side node. An alternative to a confidence value would be a predicted 
value min and max. If the net is unsure it can return a wide range - I 
wonder, does this run counter to my above argument?

> Most of the time I would expect 
>the network to return zero values, but once in a while where
>it thinks a stock has suddenly entered a predictable domain I would hope 
>it would put it's hand up with a strong buy or sell signal. For
>1 stock this may happen once every few months, but by applying it to 
>every stock in the FTSE 350 and S&P 1000 every night, I
>would hope to get a few good candidates a week which would definitely be 
>enough to make a lot of money IF (and obviously it's a
>big IF) the network has learned to 'fill it's boots' only when it thinks 
>there's a very good opportunity available.
>  
>
Yes, I agree with the concept and I expect this is similar to the setup 
currently used by automated trading agents at large banks. No reason why 
we shouldn't try it ourselves though eh.

>Choosing the fitness function to try to drive this sort of behaviour is 
>obviously critical - I have a few ideas, I guess I will just have to try
>different things out and see what works well on historical time series. 
>  
>
My guess is that the shape of price curves is going to be important. 
Now, if we apply each historical price in turn (serial) then the network 
must build up an ongoing memory that it can then analyse at each time 
step. This has the benefit of allowing longer and longer lengths of 
history to be applied easily. The downside is that a network must evolve 
structures to store data before it can be analysed - which to my mind is 
makign a difficult problem a lot harder.

Now, you could just apply the past, say, 14 days prices to the input 
layer. Bu twhat if some of the patterns in the price are over long 
periods? we want to pick up on those as well right? And my intuition 
tells me that the serial approach won't be able to develop memories to 
pick up on these long term patterns, at least not easily.

I'll leave you with those thoughts for now :)

>I have no idea wether any of this will actually work. If it does, then 
>I'm in the money. If not, I will have learned a hell of a lot trying.
>  
>
I think it would be healthy to not expect riches from this sort of 
thing, just be happy with having an engaging problem that you can learn 
a lot from - and that /might/ throw something up just to keep your 
interest level up :)

>I'm currently impelementing my own C++ version of NEAT which is heavily 
>based on Ken's C++ code, but removing all the redundant stuff like
>traits and recurrence which won't be needed for what I'm trying to do.
>  
>
Well I'm a C# evangelist these days. I've done a lot of work putting 
SharpNEAT together - this weekend I'm going to be doing some fine tuning 
to eek out a bit more performance, although right now it's pretty tight 
code anyway. If you haven't already checked it out and want to have a 
look just type sharpneat into google.


Colin
